page.title: 01Taffs Well/Caerphilly Common
page.content: The locality studied lies sandwiched between Caerphilly to the north, and Cardiff to the south. The area is known locally as the "Border Ridges" as it overlooks and separates the Vale of Glamorgan and the Cardiff Basin in the south, from the massive presence of the S.Wales Coalfield to the north. It is essentially an upland region, rising to over 800 feet (270 metres) in places, notably Craig yr Allt (GR 134851) and Caerphilly Common (GR 154855). There is, however, a tendency for the northern fringe to be at a slightly higher altitude in relation to the southern part. Only in the extreme west of the area is the pattern markedly interrupted by the presence of the River Taff which has etched into this region creating a quite spectacular gorge-like feature.
